April 2025...

As part of the candidating process it is highly recommended that a journal is kept. Indeed, it forms part of 'The Portfolio'. Well, here's mine. I've flip-flopped from a simple email to myself to capture rough reflections and thoughts, to using the superb 'Day One' Journaling app and then an email from The Connexional Team pops in asking for volunteers to capture the process. I can't ignore that.

Hello,

You are receiving this email because you have submitted an application for DOV1.
We are glad that you are in the process of discerning if you are being called by God to ordained ministry in the British Methodist Church.
It would be really helpful to others who may be discerning their own call in the future if some of you were prepared to document your journey of discernment. We are keen to tell some of these stories to inspire and inform the whole church.
You can do this in various ways (journaling, video diaries, blogs etc).
If you indicate that you are interested then more information will be given to you.

It's personal. It may (or may not) get me into trouble. But...it is me.

I'll keep using Day One...not everything can be published! But, for those journal entries that may be useful for others going through this process, or for those who are curiously wondering how this holy shift turns out - join me.

Comments, welcomed

I split my posts largely down the middle. A public 'teaser', followed by the rest of the post available for those who have signed in. All of it is free.

  • This online journal is intentional; it captures the moments of this journey or a reflection that I think may be felt or shared by others.
    • Or not...and that's ok.
  • The opportunity to comment or mirror my reflection, (I feel like that's a mixed metaphor), may need some light-touch control. Please feel free to comment, ask questions or get in touch but to do so, you just 'sign up'. Free.

Newsletter, delivered

Stay up to date with new content sent straight to your inbox! No more worrying about whether you missed something because of a pesky algorithm or news feed.

• Local Preacher‚Äôs Meeting has happened and I‚Äôm now officially On Trial. ü•≥
  • Incredible devotions form AB from John‚Äôs Gospel
  • Returned from LP meeting and sent the DOV email - to gov.uk! (thanks Gmail autocorrect!)...noticed immediately and sent it to the correct address. The State now know that this is also happening.

And here it is then, The Holy Shift. A journal, blog, a determined effort to document this journey. It'll capture the gritty, the tussles, the confusion, the hope, the joy, the laughter and (all being well and) the shift from this little world of mine to God's.

What am I praying for Today?

  • A swift response re: DOV
  • Smooth admin; countless forms all methodically scheduled in a well-published timeline
  • Balance re: work.

People to pray for

  • AS; He‚Äôs got such a big move coming up, the seeds are planted, the harvest will happen without him.
  • PD; I do hope becomes open to process. It‚Äôs going to be a rocky ride otherwise.

Things to thank God for

  • The LP Meeting
  • The support of local people as I discern next steps
  • MHM; she‚Äôs so encouraging

Verse(s) of the day

  • Psalm 19:7 (NIV): 7 The law of the LORD is perfect,
    refreshing the soul.
    The statutes of the LORD are trustworthy,
    making wise the simple.
  • Psalm 19:14 (NIV): 14 May these words of my mouth and this meditation of my heart be pleasing in your sight, LORD, my Rock and my Redeemer.
  • Mark 1:7‚Äì8 (NIV): 7 And this was his message: ‚ÄúAfter me comes the one more powerful than I, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to stoop down and untie. 8 I baptise you with water, but he will baptise you with the Holy Spirit.‚Äù
  • Mark 1:12 (NIV): 12 At once the Spirit sent him out into the wilderness,
  • Mark 1:16‚Äì18 (NIV): 16 As Jesus walked beside the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew casting a net into the lake, for they were fishermen. 17 ‚ÄúCome, follow me,‚Äù Jesus said, ‚Äúand I will send you out to fish for people.‚Äù 18 At once they left their nets and followed him.

Verse Thoughts & Reflections

  • Psalm 19 is assured, confident and unwavering. I love it.
  • Many preachers start with Psalm 19:14.
  • John the Baptist is assured in his ministry and almost excited about the contrast of who will follow him. The idea of the Holy Spirit (instead of water!)
  • At once. No delay, nothing. Instant. Jesus‚Äô testing did not wait...
  • And the day DOV gets sent away Mark 1:17; ‚ÄúCome, follow me.‚Äù OK then.

• Giddy, why hasn‚Äôt the DOV office replied by 10am!?? üòÇ, struggling to concentrate.
  • Wonderfully supportive exchange with (R)MG and lovely text from (R)AB:
  • DOV Office have acknowledged the application - asking me to check that I‚Äôd sent everything I was asked to (I have).
  • It‚Äôs nice to see (R)CP's name again - I‚Äôd met her at an online ‚ÄòExploring Ministry‚Äô course - her husband was in boarding. It‚Äôs good to think she‚Äôs basically i/c.
  • Had a call with VL re: Sunday‚Äôs service in Bentham.

Genesis 3:1‚Äì3 (NIV): 3 Now the serpent was more crafty than any of the wild animals the LORD God had made. He said to the woman, ‚ÄúDid God really say, ‚ÄòYou must not eat from any tree in the garden‚Äô?‚Äù 2 The woman said to the serpent, ‚ÄúWe may eat fruit from the trees in the garden, 3 but God did say, ‚ÄòYou must not eat fruit from the tree that is in the middle of the garden, and you must not touch it, or you will die.‚Äô "

Mark 2:17 (NIV): 17 On hearing this, Jesus said to them, ‚ÄúIt is not the healthy who need a doctor, but the sick. I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners.‚Äù

Commentary suggests that Eve doesn‚Äôt accurately recall God‚Äôs words:

The serpent‚Äôs question omits the positive statement made by God in Gen 2:16. The serpent also distorts the earlier statement by presenting God as saying Adam and Eve could not eat from any tree at all.
3:2 We may eat The woman corrects the serpent‚Äôs wording, but she does not do so precisely. Instead of echoing 2:16, where God gave the human couple permission to eat from every tree except one, she generalizes the permission, noting simply that they may eat of the trees in the garden.

  • The whole truth and nothing but the truth...The WHOLE truth. Part truths can be dangerous. It‚Äôs a lie, Context is missing.
  • A quip from Jesus - As LRGM would say, ‚ÄúLike, Duh‚Äù. The righteous (whoever they are) do not need Jesus. It‚Äôs everyone else...or simply, everyone.
  • Mark 2:1‚Äì28, NIV, https://ref.ly/Mk2.1-28;niv2011) An incredible concentration of Jesus ‚Äòin action!

An incredible 3-service-Sunday!

The morning started with a challenging (covenant) service led by my Tutor in Dent. I took Janice and we both thought there was an 'air' about the service.

This was followed by a joyful, warm service at Ravenstondale. Nancy, she's superb; so happy playing and the congregation so supportive and receptive.

Then off to Winton - one of the month's highlights for the whole family. Eve spoke beautifully. Vulnerable, honest and called to serve. Inspirational.

So I have been matched by the Connexional Team with Deacon Mark. and just as I was re-reading my email to him with introductions - he rings:

Dear Mark,

Well, this is exciting.  We've been matched as part of DOV1.

I understand the process of becoming an accompanist is itself demanding and I am so very grateful that you have offered to take on such a role.  It's so humbling that people are willing to serve in this way and to support me as I (and the church) undertake this journey of discernment.

Anyhoo, I know we've got quite a bit to get through as we look at DOV1 together and I wonder how you'd feel about meeting up in person?  I can travel to you, or I'm happy to host you in Sedbergh, whichever is more convenient for you.

A few options would be a really good start and I'm sure we can make one work.  Email or ring at any time - contact details below.  If I can't take a call, I'll ring you back as soon as I can.
All the very best,
Matt

We've covered some practicalities re: meeting times and places. How very real. He seems very organised, gentle. I must look into the Diaconate.

Church was incredible, stitched thread creating a beautiful complete tapestry.  I led an all age address at Cornerstone: 1 Cor 12:12-26 One body, many parts.

The vestry prayer was somewhat challenging - something about ensuring Sunday is dedicated to prayer - but it was styled in such a way that one should keep a list of things for Sunday.  Nope.

I had several missed calls during the Service.  It was work ringing to get NoK details for a colleague who died suddenly in his sleep.  Just awful.  He was a man of faith, I‚Äôve texted Padre re: support and prayers.

Met Mark at The Hub in Tebay.  Wow.  I was so nervous and yet he made me feel incredibly relaxed, very open and honest and a good connection. We've got a lot to 'get through'...

I then went to watch LRGM 'play' Netball but arrived early and went into the local church and found a prayer folder. Each page was split into three sections:

  • People who had died.
  • People who were unwell.
  • Things to be thankful for.

It was the 12th March 2023 since the last mention of something to be thankful for, until today:

  • The first signs of Spring
  • A deepening faith in our Lord Jesus
  • A community united (there had been a dreadful event in the town)

I then went to watch LRGM 'play' Netball but arrived early and went into the local church and found a prayer folder. Each page was split into three sections:

 * People who had died.
 * People who were unwell.
 * Things to be thankful for.

It was the 12th March 2023 since the last mention of something to be thankful for, until today:

 * The first signs of Spring
 * A deepening faith in our Lord Jesus
 * A community united (there had been a dreadful event in the town)

On holiday I normally pretend I‚Äôm away, panic about what I‚Äôve missed and irritate my team by ‚Äòchecking in‚Äô. I need a break, they need a break too. Have I read the bible? Bits of it.

So, here‚Äôs the plan:

  • Read the Bible.
  • All of it.
  • In one week.

I‚Äôm not the first to do this, and I really hope I‚Äôm not the last. A quick Google on the Wednesday before I broke up for my holiday explains the process and points to some valuable resources.

As recommended, I purchased this

Chronological Bible

Large Print (It's not that large!)

From Amazon

It arrived on Friday, the same day I told MHM of my plan. It was to start Sunday and finish on Saturday. I also let my church pastoral contact, Janice, know.

Day 1

‚úÖ

Day 2

David and Saul's next battle might be over the headache they've created.

Day 3

‚ÄòI‚Äôd rather have a bowl of vegetables with someone I love than a steak with someone I hate.‚Äô Or‚Ä¶‚ÄôWe can make our own plans but our Lord will determine the steps.‚Äô So Proverbs featured.

As did the conclusion of Solomon, the rather racy Song of Songs, and lots of Kings, most of whom appear to fail to learn. All rather bloody‚Ä¶

Elijah and Elisha featured heavily and at times rather miraculously in some very complex times.

Day 4

Jonah was a gentle start. Incredibly hard work. By far the hardest day.

Amos‚Äô anger continues with some of the other prophets receiving equally damning outcomes to pass on. Isaiah becomes somewhat less hopeful in the latter part with the enormity of God becoming very very clear. Jeremiah is a confusing jumble of beautiful prose, earthly destruction with snippets as sad as Hosea and Messianic prophecy as hopeful as Isaiah.

More Kings, Micah, Chronicles, Psalms, Zephaniah‚Ä¶ things are warming up.

Kings Hezekiah and Josiah are good eggs (or at least not bad figs!), though Josiah‚Äôs clarity and eÔ¨Éciency of mission is terrifying. Beyond that there is a frustrating lack of compliance from the people of Israel and Judah.

The Babylonian exile is confusing and Daniel (who also goes by Baltheazzar‚Ä¶because we definitely need more names) is interpreting Nebuchadnezzar‚Äôs dreams.

My head is spinning and although I am frustrated by the lack of scriptural understanding (or opportunity to dive) MHM is encouraging, and says I‚Äôm talking like quite a lot has sunk in.

Roll on the NT, it‚Äôs time for some evidenced salvation.

Day 5

At 2pm I finished the OT.

At 2.10pm I was in St Andrew‚Äôs, I prayed; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù and ‚Äúthank you‚Äù.

I visited Janice.

I cried.

Today has finished with Jairus‚Äô daughter ‚Äòwaking up‚Äô. A whirlwind dash of miracles and healings and political upset. I particularly like Luke‚Äôs style.

What a day.

Day 6

From Jesus‚Äô early ministry (the roman coin made me laugh out loud!) through to arrest, conviction, death and resurrection and then to Acts, early church founding, extensive travelling and the very human troubles experienced by early believers, and the conflict (still) with champions of the old ways‚Ä¶wow.

The clarity of The Message, The (new) Way, the freedom and salvation so soon after the death and resurrection of Jesus described with such conviction and confidence by Paul in Galatians is stunning.

Perhaps a little in contrast to the rule book he goes on to write in Corinthians - beautiful writing, sublime (divine), breathtaking. And then in places, probably because of the utter accessibility of the language used, one may respond with an ‚Äòouch‚Äô‚Ä¶and then I found myself checking the date again‚Ä¶still only About 25 years after Jesus had died‚Ä¶but it's only 3 days since I read from the scripture now being quoted. The connecting threads bring only further clarity.

So Paul has been on his three tours, he has written and preached beautifully; having moved so quickly from the Gospels I'm amazed at the warmth Paul writes to the Romans, especially when I consider (the quickly researched context of the Jewish expulsion and re-admittance by the Roman Empire)...I particularly like Paul's chummy 'say hellos' towards the end of some of his letters...I paraphrase.

..and just as I begin to breathe a sigh of relief, Paul has returned to Jerusalem...my day has ended with the words 'and the crowd followed behind, shouting "Kill him, kill him!"'

Hang on, I've already been there once today. This is exhausting.

Day 7

Well, it is done.

Paul appears to be in Rome‚Ä¶though I understand he‚Äôd hoped to get to Spain.

The political structures of the empire combined with the ‚Äòwhat?‚Äô-like response from the Roman folk at Paul‚Äôs continuing detention was fascinating. His writing continued to be beautiful.

James. Wow. Succinct.

It clicked that the Gospel‚Äôs Luke was with Paul‚Ä¶fascinating‚Ä¶

The Love of God, Jesus is the way. To do anything else is to deny Jesus. Powerful throughout.

The final words of Paul in 2 Timothy are both joyous, full of hope and eager anticipation but so, so sad.

The early exasperation of Hebrews‚Ä¶and the description (again) of the tearing of the curtain hiding the most holy place which is now accessible to us all‚Ä¶

It was by faith‚Ä¶It was by faith‚Ä¶It was by faith‚Ä¶

I think Hebrews is one of my favourites.

3 John screams of the Wesleyan-like support of itinerant mission. I read the first half of Revelation sat in a pew in St Andrew‚Äôs. I read the symbol-heavy second half on my knees at the top altar: (I couldn‚Äôt keep being deaf to the words ‚Äòcome up here‚Äô)

After I finished (and wiped away my tears), I closely examined the cross. In the centre, bathed in bright sunlight, was the Lamb of God.

Lord, I am sorry. Thank you. Amen.

3 John screams of the Wesleyan-like support of itinerant mission. I read the first half of Revelation sat in a pew in St Andrew‚Äôs. I read the symbol-heavy second half on my knees at the top altar: (I couldn‚Äôt keep being deaf to the words ‚Äòcome up here‚Äô)

After I finished (and wiped away my tears), I closely examined the cross. In the centre, bathed in bright sunlight, was the Lamb of God.

Lord, I am sorry. Thank you. Amen.

posts.html:
After a service at The Sands...

The dialogue with these two, especially Gill was incredible.  Slightly uncomfortable and very punchy opener from Gill about the timescales for entering ministry.  The agreed "What makes you say that?", was beautifully brushed aside by Gill and she went for it.

She then followed up by email:

Evening Matt,

Richard and I want to apologise for putting our two big feet into your situation and appearing to be intrusive.

We certainly had not intended that to be the case.When I asked someone if you were thinking of becoming a presbyter I was told you were probably candidating in January. I am so sorry. I only asked him as it was so obvious that this is what you should be doing! Please accept our apology for presuming you wanted to discuss it at all or even with us.

We were so pleased to see you again and folks at Appleby love having you. Please come again soon! We look forward to having opportunities to meet your family. Trust today has been a good day for you.

Very best wishes and prayers 

I replied:

Good evening both,

You‚Äôre so kind to write - and there really is no need to apologise. The subject has cropped up a number of times, from various corners, and I appear to have a strategy along the lines of ‚Äòwhat makes you say that‚Äô - I‚Äôm certainly not going to lie about it and it is an incredibly affirming (and ridiculously humbling) moment when my call appears to be recognised by others.

Nothing's 'been let out of the bag' - it‚Äôs a tricky question to answer and I retuned from the service yesterday and shared our encounters with Margie. She smiled.

Oh, what a challenge. It was refreshing to talk so candidly and openly about the logistics of such a ‚Äòdirectional shift‚Äô with you Gill and Richard‚Äôs wise counsel (and shared love of strong singing) was also so welcome.

Who knows what will happen, (God?), I am in the very first official stages of the process now - wonderfully titled Discerning Ordained Vocation 1.

It all comes to a head at the retreat in May as to whether I have had sufficient clarity to test this call alongside the Methodist church and if so I move on to‚Ä¶drum roll‚Ä¶DOV2. Fearful levels of organisation are being applied and I have the support of a few in and around Sedbergh including my mentor, my superintendent and my minister but most importantly my family appear to be completely alongside.

Again, thank you so much for reaching out this evening, I am very moved by you both doing so. I really do enjoy coming to The Sands and always receive such a warm welcome. It is the most diverse congregation I‚Äôve experienced in the circuit - with their joys and challenges - I love it!

I‚Äôll be back in a few weeks time to share a service with Andrew, I can‚Äôt wait. See you soon. I hope you both have a fulfilling week.

With all best wishes and prayerful thanks,

Matt 

Erm. Wow.

posts.html:
I prepped for a meeting with the Circuit's Superintendent this week. Anticipating discussion re: C2 Candidating Context Form:

Please do not make this application unless you have first met with your Superintendent Minister and your Chair of District to discuss your calling to an already identified circuit or district or to a specific context

Much of the guidance talks about how early engagement (and submission) of this form is required. It's mentioned in G1.1, G.9, G.10, D.4 and more and has to be done in agreement with the District.

Prep done but it lead to a conversation with Margie re: her job and my training routes.  CBLP looks attractive because of the speed in which active ministry begins, BUT it would be a slower route to proper station going compared to full time - which essentially looks like 5 terms (over two years). We know school terms - they‚Äôre short, they fly...It‚Äôs preferable to go Full Time.

Margie sees the drop in salary and the move to grant based income for a short while.  She‚Äôs mentioned selling the house - I‚Äôm encouraging her to hold firm - there are lots of options when sitting on the equity. We really have been blessed to even consider this seriously.

Margie sent me a link to a house. It wasn't serious, the last time she did that we bought it! She's open to options though - the house we're in now is spectacular, too big, too expensive...but lovely. I'd like to hold on to it if we can.

I had a meeting with our Superintendent...

I've captured the outcomes and will follow up. We were in total agreement regarding steps. The timings are complicated by new Circuit prep (Cumbria is becoming one Circuit...and further complicated by her move to a new Circuit. That said I'm thrilled that she's got a spark about her new station. They'll be lucky to have her.

There appears to have been a letter doing the rounds that has upset some people. I expect it will be to do with the God for All approach and God in Love Unites Us that has caused division. I continue to observe with an ignorance and blessed naivety; (though I continue to be frustrated) how does a 'single topic' (over simplifying) continue to consume so much time?

Clother the naked. Home the homeless. Feed the hungry. Then chat to me about same sex relationships. Over simplified(!?). God's Love is for all. Not just for those we say can have it. Urgh.

posts.html:
I received a somewhat mysterious email from our Superintendent re: C2. I think there's been a misunderstanding along the way with what I mean by 'local context'. I'm thinking this...

I've sent the draft form to a few folk (as suggested in the guidance) and wait to hear...will nudge often. It can't be included in the main bundle unless it's been agreed. I wrote about this here.

I said in my draft:

I am very aware of the itinerant nature, requirements and benefits of ordained Methodist ministry, and I submit this application in the understanding that initial probationary stationing is not guaranteed (or indeed likely) and circumstances may change during training.  

However, with the merging of several districts to form the NWED (September 2024) and several Circuits merging to form the Cumbria Circuit (September 2025), I hope that this application may be considered in light of the benefits such enlarged structures may bring to support a probationer being stationed in the area identified.

I expect it might not end up being included in the main bundle. I wonder if it's going to ruffle too many feathers.

posts.html:
I had my second DOV 1 meeting with the wonderful Mark. We shared in God-centred fellowship and sought further clarity re: calling and vocation. It was superb. Our match is a blessing and a gift in itself. I come away with further clarity, affirmation of call and supportive guidance.

Further thoughts to this:...

Think 20 years ago and the preacher who stood up and claimed the benefits of God for All and the welcoming and blessing of same sex relationships would have felt as nervous doing so as the preacher who stands up today and preaches against.  20 years...it‚Äôs nothing.  It‚Äôs the amount of time I‚Äôve been in the north.  The congregation hasn‚Äôt actually changed.  My naivety is being balanced by reflection. It is so difficult.

In which order do I place; Belong, Believe, Behave...? Probably that order.

posts.html:
I led a service and preached at the wonderful Brough Sowerby. A small dales chapel

Why use 2 readings...when you can use 3! The Gospel is alive. I love that I was advised in a service some months ago that I shouldn't choose 2 readings because I felt obliged to. It was said in such a way that 1 will suffice. Ha!...

From Moses to Luke to Paul, the connecting threads were irresistible and it was well received.

Lovely warmth of fellowship at the end of the service. I was joined by another LP who I'd heard at Ravenstondale, she was very moved.

It was a 'trad' service - because, that's what fed their souls. That's ok.

King of Kings doesn't work with a congregation of 6. üòÜ.

A little post-service, evening reflection: one must be so, so careful at the pulpit; Our words, actions, songs and message is food for the souls of many. We must be so, so careful. (Worth repeating!).

posts.html:
I started the day with the family at Cornerstone, and nervously paced around the House for 30 minutes before setting off to Garsdale Low Smith for an 'assessed service'. Wow. The first Sunday of Lent, I'm not exactly short of material! I Was expecting 6 or so. Circa. 20 were in the congregation and the singing was incredible. I wasn't sure my voice was going to hold up. The organist was class! I'll write a note of thanks.

Feedback from the congregation was utterly affirming.

Then...

off to Bentham for the rescheduled 'youth' meeting. What a contrast in service type. And yet the pattern of challenge and reassurance as the key takeaways appears to work at both.

Vic led the Bentham gathering so skilfully and naturally. It was so nice to see some of the family there and the worship was joyful and energetic.

What a day. What a privilege.

posts.html:
I think every church, every circuit, every gathering of people probably includes 'a Frank'. My Frank is an incredible man; self-confessed grump, stoic, deeply interesting with a fascinating, encyclopaedic knowledge - of almost any subject.

Frank likes things Frank's way. And that's ok. There's a balance to strike between leading a service and being led. Apply the context, 'read the room', all of that matters. Frank was able to brief me well in advance via text in the build up to our service (it's not 'mine')....

  • We only like plonk plonk hymns
  • Nothing modern
  • Bring dynamism

I love Frank. We shared fellowship on the way to and from the chapel (I picked him up so he could play - no car), we welcomed visitors, we worshipped and prayed together and I couldn't have been more pleased with the warmth of those gathered in some challenging times.

Thank you Frank.

posts.html:
Lots of comparisons of LP training and holding down jobs at the same time...Yes, but 20 years ago without 13 hour days and 160 emails? I am tired.

There‚Äôs been a lot of over sharing of todo lists and busyness today (not in this meeting, just generally and at work)...it‚Äôs been triggering, I just want to spend quality time with people. I am tired. And possibly a little grumpy.

That said, affirming and supportive feedback from the minister and my mentor.

Good result...

I need to remind myself that this is experience for whatever comes next. Supervision, feedback, input, guidance - it needs to be accepted gracefully and know it's done so from a position of love and support. It's not a secular appraisal!

I probably do need to scale back the appointments a little bit, find some time to log back in to the eLearning platform and submit some module evidence. In a rather welcome turn we do not need to have quite so many assessed services each quarter as we had originally thought. CPD out in force...and being helpful.

Some very accessible, warm devotions at the start of the meeting and Margie's going to lead them in next meeting.

posts.html:
Incredible meeting with Mark. I went well prepared after he suggested the topics for conversation in advance.

We went through the competencies framework, (G.6) we were both surprised/encouraged by the evidence against most. There was some conversation about my ‚Äòtigger‚Äô like mood. That's not to say lots of ups and downs...more 'boing boing'.

We‚Äôre both really excited about the next steps and we both agreed Frank is a legend...

We had a shared reflection on the learning section and the child-like response to seeing connections in scripture. There was also a gentle moment of appreciation where I reflected upon Margie‚Äôs rock-like support.  Mark‚Äôs really excited about the journey's progress and next steps. So am I. I can't actually put it into words - that will have to get resolved.

There's something very special about sharing 'God moments'.

I shared with Margie 3 things:

1) Her mum needs an update. It will not come as a surprise this is happening, but she will want to know before it becomes more widely known.

2) When (if!) I start training I need to leave everything at the door,  Neatly packed up in a waterproof bag...but left nonetheless, I can collect and sort through when I finish. What a wonderful analogy.

3) My big V...is a P for People.

I also emailed our Superintendent to seek permission to reach out to the person i/c matters at a District level. C.2 is still sat as a draft (though circulated), undiscussed. She approved that approach. Brace. Brace:

posts.html:
A superb resource from 'Thy Kingdom Come'

Thy Kingdom Come is a global ecumenical prayer movement that invites Christians around the world to pray for more people to come to know Jesus. What started in 2016 as an invitation from the Archbishops of Canterbury and York to the Church of England has grown into an international and ecumenical call to prayer.

An 11 day up-to-Pentecost daily reading and reflection. I read them all...

...It uses The Lord‚Äôs Prayer, line by line with commentary and reflection from contributors (including the previous chaplain to the House of Commons - how did she ever put up with John Bercow as Speaker!? (though he is actually my favourite ever 'Marmite' figure). Pastoral care almost certainly took over her evangelical roots from The Church Army - although she will be well armed.

I like the focus on the word OUR in Our Father, and have yet to find another commentary talk about the ‚ÄòDaily Bread‚Äô as being sufficient to meet ones needs...it wasn‚Äôt in this either.

So, this is me, Matt.

I work as the Director of IT at a boarding school in Cumbria, UK. Having previously been a Housemaster and a teacher of Business Studies I have been at the School for nearly 20 years - moving 'up north' following a stint in London at the birth of the 'dot-com-boom'.

Away from the day job I am a Methodist Local Preacher (On Trial!) and discerning God's call to Ordained Ministry in the Methodist Church. (Woah!!, What!??)

I'm married to the wonderful Margie (‚ù§Ô∏è) and together we have a 13 year old daughter, LRGM (‚ù§Ô∏è) and an 18 month Beagle/Cocker, Riley (üêæ)

The District Lead for all things vocation and ministries and I are meeting tomorrow evening. I‚Äôm looking forward to sharing in fellowship and getting to know each other a little more. It‚Äôs been a challenge getting into his diary - work rudely putting a sudden halt to my holiday last night focussed the mind....

In Methodism we only ever seem to be about 1.5 degrees of separation from someone else ‚Äòknown‚Äô, rather than the usual six:

It‚Äôll be interesting to share stories of our time in Cumbria and obtain some clarity re: the dreaded C2...

A simply superb visit yesterday with a very learned, kind and encouraging person who has known Margie for many years and was a missionary in India. She'll be there on Sunday too...I was gifted the most incredible NIV concordance. It‚Äôs utterly addictive - even from a very basic ‚ÄòI wonder how many times word X appears...‚Äô It‚Äôs become the new coffee-table book. If it were any bigger and had legs it could become a coffee table, it‚Äôs massive!

I told LRGM the word 'no' appears over 1700 times in the NIV; she doesn't need to start every sentence with it!

A rather engineered afternoon tea in the yard with Margie‚Äôs mum yesterday afternoon and she‚Äôs now fully up to speed; as predicted she wasn‚Äôt surprised but she will reflect deeply and ask questions as they arise. There will be plenty. It‚Äôs comforting to think she will be praying both for clarity and support.

Nighttime sermon writing for Palm Sunday at Stricklandgate. I‚Äôm pleased with the outcome. I had a run through with Margie, including a play through of the hymns to ensure flow. I cracked and had tears and Margie wobbled. Probably a good sign of a strong and hopeful message. I am struck by the paradoxical nature of the events building up to Holy Week. The celebration of Passover whilst under Roman occupation. The cheering of the crowds welcoming Jesus into Jerusalem only for those cheers to change to cries of ‚Äúcrucify him‚Äù. The interaction of the Pharisees with Jesus, and his assured, snappy response! Like my sermon on the first Sunday of Lent, there is a certain ‚Äòpunch‚Äô to this one as we march into Holy Week.

I‚Äôve sensed, and it‚Äôs been suggested that, a ‚Äòtrad‚Äô service will be welcomed. I‚Äôm including a hymn from 1664; the third verse is incredibly challenging:

Sometimes they strew His way,
and His sweet praises sing;
resounding all the day
hosannas to their King.
Then ‚ÄúCrucify!‚Äù is all their breath,
and for His death they thirst and cry.

Traditional is ok.

Although the morning was at work, my focussed mind-set continued for the afternoon and I spent the most glorious time with my beautiful, beautiful family. Thank you Lord, today has been a good day.

posts.html:
What an inspirational person.

I continue to be bowled over by the kindness, encouragement and support of those I meet on this journey....

Just short of an hour's drive there got me all 'wound up', and the journey home allowed for me to reflect and review. This resulted in a bit of a jumble:

1) Our meeting was totally dominated by what must have come across as a rather fragmented and somewhat chaotic download from my mind!  My uncurbed enthusiasm and excitement about what may be next (and the opportunity to secure time in a packed diary) ran away from me. Silly boy.

2) I missed an incredible opportunity to hear more from someone else about their call and journey.  We didn't really touch on it.  I particularly reflected upon the family / school-aged children elements of their journey - to hear from others about this side of things will be so valuable going forward for Margie and I, and I must make space in conversations going forward to allow for this to happen.

Part of the meeting, but thankfully by no means the most dominant, was the C2 form admin:

We concluded that we would allow the processes to take their course but more importantly God's will to be done.

The draft form in itself is useful as a 'position' statement but really little more than that. I have repeatedly remarked of the benefits I and my family see of itinerant methodist ministry and any context that would need to be factored in come the appropriate time would be part of established processes. I am so relieved to have such clarity and shared insight from this meeting. It no longer needs to be...'a thing'...at this stage and I can now focus on the final meeting with Mark in preparation for the DOV 1 retreat. A massive ‚úÖ.

posts.html:
Q: When‚Äôs a party, not a party? A: When it‚Äôs at your house. It‚Äôs one of my favourite quips from the outrageously sweary political ‚Äòfly on the wall‚Äô comedy, The Thick of It. (NOT for the faint hearted or easily offended)

But I had one of those moments. Someone, forthright and unfiltered, launched into a fairly dismissive critique of the work of the local mission community - casually dropped into conversation as if they were commenting on the weather.

I wasn‚Äôt offended. Just‚Ä¶ confused...

Ecumenism at this level doesn‚Äôt suit everyone. I understand that. In fact, perhaps that‚Äôs part of the reason it needs a name. If it came naturally, it would simply be church, or worship, or our faith‚Äîsomething we didn‚Äôt need to label. But still, there‚Äôs a time and a place for expressing concerns. For asking questions, for being heard. This wasn‚Äôt it. And in truth, it wasn‚Äôt healthy or helpful.

I felt oddly fine myself‚Äîthick-skinned, maybe‚Äîbut aware that others might have felt second-hand discomfort. That quiet sort of embarrassment people feel for someone else‚Äôs sake. Strange sensation, really.

What stayed with me was how far the view expressed seemed from what I felt to be true. And that‚Äôs what made it a little more than just an awkward moment. There was a visiting vicar present‚Äîsomeone I‚Äôve met a few times before. I might drop her a line, just to offer a different, more hopeful account of good work in mission community. Not to rebut or challenge, but to share a fuller picture. A small rebalancing, perhaps.

It was also a lovely party.

posts.html:
A service of thanksgiving this evening to mark the 50th anniversary of the Church Sharing Agreement between the Anglicans and Catholics and their joint use of the building. It was combined with a service visiting the Stations of the Cross.

Elements were taken from the service marking the agreement in 1975 with the following reading:

John 17:1‚Äì2 (NIV): 17 After Jesus said this, he looked toward heaven and prayed:
‚ÄúFather, the hour has come. Glorify your Son, that your Son may glorify you. 2 For you granted him authority over all people that he might give eternal life to all those you have given him.
John 17:13‚Äì24 (NIV): 13 ‚ÄúI am coming to you now, but I say these things while I am still in the world, so that they may have the full measure of my joy within them. 14 I have given them your word and the world has hated them, for they are not of the world any more than I am of the world. 15 My prayer is not that you take them out of the world but that you protect them from the evil one. 16 They are not of the world, even as I am not of it. 17 Sanctify them by the truth; your word is truth. 18 As you sent me into the world, I have sent them into the world. 19 For them I sanctify myself, that they too may be truly sanctified.
20 ‚ÄúMy prayer is not for them alone. I pray also for those who will believe in me through their message, 21 that all of them may be one, Father, just as you are in me and I am in you. May they also be in us so that the world may believe that you have sent me. 22 I have given them the glory that you gave me, that they may be one as we are one‚Äî23 I in them and you in me‚Äîso that they may be brought to complete unity. Then the world will know that you sent me and have loved them even as you have loved me.
24 ‚ÄúFather, I want those you have given me to be with me where I am, and to see my glory, the glory you have given me because you loved me before the creation of the world.

Key take away: We must / will / have to‚Ä¶seek unity in Christ. I had this song going round my head after the reading:

We also prayed this prayer:

You shall pray that all within the several denominations of Christ‚Äôs Church may, under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, seek to end divisions and be led into unity with one another in serving him.

(I added formatting with my pen in the service!).

I sat quietly at the end of the service for just a few moments and was deeply moved by the absence of the Cross on the altar. The Lamb of God is on an indescribable journey.

Is there really objection to the mission community as a concept?:

No.  Instead perhaps one is understandably, in local context, a little lost. In some gentle, reflective fellowship after tonight‚Äôs service this was clear. It was followed by a shared love of some music, especially the contemporary classical...always pushing the edge, think Peter Maxwell Davis.

No one could have attended that service and seen the incredible diversity of denominational representation and think that the Mission Community is not being guided by the Holy Spirit and being led into unity with one another. Beautiful.

posts.html:
I continue to be somewhat overwhelmed at the privilege of preaching and today was no exception. I was welcomed at Striklandgate like a well known friend. They were looking forward to the service and I was looking forward to leading them in worship. What I hadn't quite expected was either the number (between 55 and 60) or the strength of fellowship both before and after the service it literally took my breath away. It was one of those occasions where everything seems to slot into place, not because of meticulous planning, but through something deeper and beautifully beyond our control...

...I felt the power of the Holy Spirit and God‚Äôs presence at Stricklandgate.  What an incredible privilege to lead worship and preach there to such faithful brothers and sisters.

My sermon attempted to capture the paradox of the day; the tension between celebration and contemplation, triumph and tragedy, kingship and servanthood. Someone kindly commented afterwards on my use of picture language. It was encouraging feedback‚ÄîI hadn't even fully realised I was doing it. It's always humbling when people see things in your words that were placed there almost subconsciously. God at work.

Several people offered generous encouragement. Words from long-established preachers and ministers are always particularly affirming. And, increasingly (and gratefully, perhaps even gracefully?), comes that gentle inquiry: "Are you in the ministry?‚Äù.  No comment, but there was certainly an inner smile.

The singing had such depth‚Äîenergetic and joyful when it needed to be, then tender and reflective in quieter moments. Sitting with our palm crosses pressed against our hearts during "My Song Is Love Unknown" was unexpectedly moving‚Äîfar more so than when I'd run through the service beforehand with Margie. My LPWL Secratary (and it was an assessed service!) described it as a brave choice but one she was pleased I made. It felt absolutely right.

Lunch followed, sharing reflections with our Superintendent. A chance to unpack our respective services and marvel together at the "God moments" we'd each experienced. It struck me again‚Äîit's Passover and Palm Sunday overlapping. I think I knew that intellectually, but today, the reality landed with deeper resonance.

Remarkably, we'd each landed on the same paradoxical conclusions in our sermons‚Äîsomething that visibly touched one minister attending my service. Moments like these confirm God's weaving threads, pulling together different strands, even across different congregations and contexts.

We had some practical discussion too, agreeing next steps for DOV 1 & DOV 2. Practicalities amid spiritual reflection.  Why not?  And like so many conversations with those supporting me on my journey it didn‚Äôt distract from our fellowship.

I also found out about The Passion play at Oberammergau...

...and the troubling misuse of Matthew‚Äôs Gospel by Hitler. Both things I‚Äôll look into during an already challenging week.

The day ended quietly with Evensong at St. Andrew's. I didn't know a single hymn, but that wasn't the point. Sitting quietly, reflecting on an incredible day, I felt well-fed spiritually.

posts.html:
I found myself in Grange this morning‚Äîbit of an unplanned detour while collecting the car from the garage. I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve ever actually been before.

The Methodist Church had its doors wide open, which felt like an invitation. I stepped inside‚Ä¶ and straight into the middle of their weekly yoga class. I backed out as quietly as I could, largely unnoticed, and with absolutely no interest in observing, let alone attempting the lotus position.

In the porch, I spent some time reading their redevelopment plans‚Äîambitious, detailed, and clearly the result of a lot of effort. The fundraising targets alone were enough to make me pause. The building has real potential. So does the cost...

I have been particularly moved over the last few days of stripped altars, or the absence of The Cross; a striking reminder of what it all means. The one at Grange, a permanent feature I think, is as naked and raw as it could be: One Cross. Three Nails.

I‚Äôd parked near the Anglican church and wandered in there too. It must have one of the most peaceful, picturesque settings and incredible outlook. I sat for a while and had a browse of their books. After about twenty minutes, I had a conversation with a very gentle man who turned out to be the church treasurer. He was delighted about the appointment of a new permanent vicar. It turned out he‚Äôd once lived in Seaford, so we ended up swapping stories about jumping off the point, steep pebble beaches, and walking the Seven Sisters. One of those five-minute chats that feels like more than it should be. No pressure, no expectations‚Äîjust a small, moment of connection.

Later in the day, I bought lunch for the team. Everyone‚Äôs worked right through the Easter ‚Äòholidays‚Äô and then some. There were raised eyebrows and actual grins when a slightly ridiculous Subway turned up‚Ä¶ complete with a footlong cookie. Over the top, but worth it.

More moderate portion sizes at the evening‚Äôs Methodist Lovefeast. I‚Äôd never been to one before and wasn‚Äôt quite sure what to expect. At first, it seemed like a curious idea. But it very quickly became something meaningful‚Äîbread, water, singing, testimonies, and a gentle reflection of the Last Supper. Honest words were shared. God was unmistakably at work.

The Mission Community was (again!!) well represented‚Äîpeople from different churches, different backgrounds, different traditions. And yet, somehow, it all felt cohesive. Together. One body.

It was a fitting Maundy Thursday: Fellowship with strangers who didn‚Äôt stay strangers, meals shared, and the quiet weight of knowing what comes next.

posts.html:
This day is so difficult.

There were around 40 of us at the first Walk of Witness. A good number, really. Margie read from Luke‚ÄîJesus promising the kingdom to the penitent thief. She read it beautifully.

I read later, at the final station: Luke 23:50‚Äì56. Joseph of Arimathea and the women from Galilee.

That moment between Joseph and Pilate‚Äîit‚Äôs never quite sat comfortably. That request for Jesus‚Äô body. The unspoken weight of it. The risk, the reverence. The cost of doing what was right.

About 25 people came to the second Walk of Witness, followed by a very solemn service at St Andrew‚Äôs in Dent. Quiet, reflective, no unnecessary words.

I walked with others...

...Slowly. Silently. Purposefully. Prayerfully.

It‚Äôs been a gentle day. Quiet. What contrast to what this day must have been like the first time round. There was something about us, ‚Äòthe crowd‚Äô, that made me feel very very uncomfortable. What would we have done?

And through it all, the simple truth: Jesus went through all of this for us.
He could‚Äôve asked his Father to stop it all‚Äîand it would‚Äôve stopped. But he didn‚Äôt. He knew. To secure our freedom, he had to go through with it.

The weather felt right‚Äînot historically, but spiritually. Not dramatic, not stormy‚Äîjust cold, grey, unsettled. Gusts of wind sweeping through at just the right moments. Slivers of sunlight cutting through the clouds like a whisper.

It felt as if God was there. Seeing it. Holding it. With us through it.

posts.html:
He is risen. Alleluia. (Part 1)

Described by the presiding minister as "Anglicanism at its very best", I couldn‚Äôt agree more:  Beautifully choreographed, the readings were delivered with a sincerity and clarity fitting of such a cornerstone moment in the church‚Äôs calendar. It was a journey of ceremony and joy.

There is something very moving about a building as vast as Kendal Parish Church being plunged into darkness lit only by the flicker of our candles ignited by the Easter flame.   Likewise, celebrating The Eucharist surrounded by splendour and magnificence.  It made me sit up straight, I prayed the Lord‚Äôs prayer on my knees in the pew and there was a fitting reverence about the whole event.

The liturgy ran to 24 pages; reflective, challenging and at times confusing - there is plenty to explore here.  In attendance; 20 clergy + 20 (or so) in the congregation.

For some reason I had expected the vigil to go on until midnight...

...making the Easter Sunrise Service at 0600 a challenge (with its preceding hour‚Äôs hike).  Thankfully, sort of, it finished by 10.00pm.  But for the first time in what has felt far too long, I have said the words:

He is Risen. Alleluia.

Alleluia indeed.

PS - This is incredible, and well worth a dedicated visit to Kendal Parish Church.

Tomorrow - Sunrise Service > Appleby > Grange! I cannot wait. I literally cannot wait!!

We are Easter People!

I have noticed that I keep describing things as ‚Äòincredible‚Äô.  Perhaps that word should be reserved for days like this.

0445 awake and ready to set off on our sunrise hike (Margie had set her alarm at 0545...in the nicest possible way, she was hurried along!)

It was going to be a stunner; still, crisp and quiet.  Everyone should be up for this.

There was an excited pace about our march to the top of the fell. We were joined by family, folk from other churches and our minister to lead a bracing, joyful service. We sang, we prayed and we declared; He is Risen. Alleluia.

A dash down the fell to warm up and recharge before heading to Appleby for...

...Andrew's last service before he goes on sabbatical which also includes the baptism of his son, Isaac.

I have spent a lot of time with Andrew over the last year, he has been my mentor in all things ministry. (I'll have more to say about him in a future post; but needless to say I wouldn't be where I am today without him. He is a brother).

I shared with Margie before I left how I hoped the singing was going to be joyful and that there was a particular chap who if we were near each other, I know we would give each other the confidence to sing our hearts out.

I was greeted by Linda, one of the wonderful stewards of The Sands, and the Circuit's Superintendent, Stephen. I couldn't believe he didn't have another service...he did. Andrew's pulled his back. He's not going to be here. I replied:

He'll find a way. He's not going to miss this.

Stephen said:

There's been much prayer.

There was going to be more. I wasn't sad, I wasn't disappointed. I prayed. Hard. Nothing sensible or coherent or easily replicated.

A section service with 4 churches, 100 or so in the congregation, two baptisms, two new members, Easter Sunday service, it was packed with Members, families, visitors - this was going to be ace. I was ushered to sit next to...the chap I mentioned to Margie before I left! No way. I texted Margie:

And directly behind...Frank. Stop it.

We opened with Thine be the Glory.

Our opening prayers; Adoration, Confession...

Andrew 'walks' in. My brother. He's made it.

Stephen carried on leading the service. Amazing singing, joyful worship. Powerful, moving, emotional message. I am convinced. Delivered beautifully.

Stephen asked me to assist in Communion. This is surreal.

The baptisms were 'wow', full submersion. We welcomed a brother and sister into our family today. They were so confident in front of so many. Promises and declarations made, gifts exchanged. ‚ù§Ô∏è.

We ended the service with my favourite Easter hymn, Stephen asked for 'gusto'...don't you worry my friend...we gave these a run for their money:

Fellowship after the service matched every moment up to that point. Unexpected encounters, shared stories of Easter joy. Andrew and I gently embraced as brothers and wished each other all the very best. (He finishes his sabbatical and immediately joins his new Circuit). That's it.

Back home to whisk the family off to Grange for ice cream along the prom and an afternoon of sharing Easter stories. I noted here:

I have been particularly moved over the last few days of stripped altars, or the absence of The Cross; a striking reminder of what it all means. The one at Grange, a permanent feature I think, is as naked and raw as it could be: One Cross. Three Nails.

Jesus Christ, Our Lord, Our Saviour, Our Redeemer and Our Friend is Risen. Alleluia.

posts.html:
There is an energy and enthusiasm about our time together; we were able to share our respective journeys through Holy Week and had much to share, both recognising the presence of the Holy Spirit throughout. We reflected on the ecumenical nature of Holy Week and how rather than labelling by denomination the ‚Äòour faith‚Äô experience was something we had both had in spades.

I had the opportunity to recall the moment on Palm Sunday where, probably for the first time that I can recall, there was a tangible presence of the Holy Spirit and for a time during that service of worship and word we were all (everyone), in the same place.  I hadn‚Äôt been able to express that before in a way that would be understood by others.  We both ‚Äògot it‚Äô...

...To hear of the challenges experienced and the moment of grace on display in the Holy Island pilgrimage was breathtaking.  Are we allowed to have a ‚Äòbucket list‚Äô for things like this?  Regardless, this is on mine:

We had a gentle, deep discussion on the concept of ‚Äòpeculiar‚Äô grace, and how there will be times when things aren‚Äôt ‚Äôalways rosy‚Äô...There is grace in ‚Äòthe darkness‚Äô, in ‚Äòfear‚Äô:

To find someone in ministry to discuss how they have coped with moments of fear; and a realisation of the openness expected in ministry.  I am anchored to the ground by the assurance of Jesus, but it allows one to be more vulnerable, (safely) there is a balance though.

There are only a few sections on the form  that we‚Äôve not covered:

  • Cost of Candidating
    • On your identify in the church (It‚Äôll change, a lot)
    • On your family & community (a lot, but timed correctly)
    • Financially (a manageable shift)
  • Creating a Portfolio (This is a DOV2 element, C7 is a really useful resource).  It‚Äôs been good to think about this in advance and how it might be structured and evidenced.
  • Interview Preparation...

I went well armed and had done my homework.  I received wise, gentle input; especially about the nature of the DOV1 Advisory Group meeting.  Key word...Advisory.  Will I really be able to portray God‚Äôs call in me and of me in such a way that it‚Äôs recognised by others in such a short time...remotely?  They‚Äôre looking for it, that surly helps? 

It was the final meeting before ‚Äòretreat‚Äô.  I‚Äôve written retreat like that because I think I‚Äôve built an image in my mind of what a retreat might be vs. what this retreat actually is:

  • Is it a a space offered? Yes.
  • Is it a facilitated opportunity, gifted by the Church, to discover further clarity of call? Yes.
  • It is not a holiday! 
  • It isn‚Äôt an escape from the realities of what this might mean for my future or that of my family.
  • It is not ‚Äòassessment free‚Ä¶.

‚Ä¶We are human; views will be made by those who will have input and influence on the next steps, that‚Äôs the reality.  So it‚Äôs a retreat.  Not a ‚Äòretreat‚Äô.  I‚Äôve rebalanced what this is.

The hardest part of this meeting, and indeed any meeting had so far, ‚ÄúWhat if it‚Äôs not this?‚Äù The official answer: There‚Äôs a ‚Äòwhere now?‚Äô retreat...(after DOV2). The honest answer is, I do not know.

I need to spend time on this, proper, reflective, prayer-filled time.  A list of pros and cons? Yes > Then What? No > Then What?

There are so many standout moments of our time together in this phase - but these will be with me daily:

And this prayer:

Silent surrender, calm & still
Open to the word of God
Heart humbled to Your will
Offered is the servant of God

(https://www.praise.org.uk/authors/hayes-pamela)

Amen.

Trepidation, Excitement.  It‚Äôs not ‚Äòassessed‚Äô, but kind of is, because people are people.  I‚Äôve had some outstanding input, feedback, pearls of wisdom, advice, guidance, thoughts and lists‚Ä¶It probably could all be summed up in one phrase ‚Äòbe you‚Äô.

I remain wholly committed and utterly humbled by the efforts of so many. People are praying for me, that‚Äôs amazing.

I‚Äôm not going to fake my way through any of this ‚Äì I am who I am.  Now, that‚Äôs not to say that for retreat I shouldn‚Äôt shift my MO.  Naturally, folk have remarked upon me being in teaching or church-leading mode.  That cannot be the default here; I must be in receive mode. A few thoughts have sprung to mind as I‚Äôve been praying and preparing.

Those few thoughts had flip-flopped from the quite serious with theological framing through to the probably silly ‚Äì but thought none-the-less.

  • I can‚Äôt wait to meet folk who are at the same point of the journey as me.
  • What do I wear? (See, silly)

So, travel down on the Friday morning.  Here we go.

PS - The personal journal is filling up - I know I've got some back-filling to do here. Perhaps quiet evenings on retreat? (or more likely sleepless nights!)

I'm not quite sure how to respond to the 'headline'. Perhaps with some further headlines. Anyone who is on this path and following this process, will remember the DOV1 Retreat all their life - they just will. It was that impactful.

So in no particular order, and with no weight applied to any individual statement (except perhaps the last one), here are my captured thoughts as the retreat went on:

The retreat exemplified the rich tapestry of God‚Äôs creation. All attendees, meeting together, stitched together like a beautiful tapestry, with our rich stories, and journeys, at the same place, discerning their call from God.

I genuinely felt this next statement; especially following extensive small group work:

When we're stripped bare, leaving baggage behind, allowing God in, only then does the armour of God fit properly.

Otherwise it's like putting a jumper on top of a jumper - it doesn't feel right.

This article was a find following a conversation with one of the authors (and one of the retreat team), this is the most recent of his publications.

The same author, as President of Conference, delivered his inaugural address on Social Holiness - if that phrase doesn't feature in my next Sermon I'll be astounded.

The theories and concepts capture almost everything the church should be, in 2025.

God isn‚Äôt elsewhere.

I prayed this, repeatedly, and have continued to do so.

What am I about to take my family through?

This question featured as the main topic of conversation during a 1:1 with a lay member of the retreat team. She is married to a Methodist minister. Our shared reflections and silent, radiating prayers, will be with me forever.

This is Christ's body, broken...for you.

I'd maintained emotional composure throughout the retreat. Hearing so many journeys of faith, witnessing God's call upon so many, and the assurance and affirmation shared amongst so many was moving (of course it was!) but nothing moved me like this moment: It was our final act of worship as a group, I observed others going for Communion, my turn...in that moment when the bread was given to me, the presiding ministers' eyes and mine locked, my upturned palm remained in place as did his hand and the bread for a fraction longer than it needed to. I've used the word tangible before to describe moments of the Holy Spirit at work. This was, without doubt, the most tangible and physically evidenced expression of what that means.

I was able to be me

9 of us were billeted or as it became quickly referred to 'in exile' at the local Premier Inn because the retreat venue didn't have enough rooms for the first night (what a superb problem to have), technical issues meant we weren't able to check-in upon arrival and some gentle organising was needed to ensure we got it resolved - I was able to be me. I engaged with the staff at reception, when I say engaged we laughed and laughed, shared stories and enjoyed each other's company, (Anne needs a medal).

I organised a table in the restaurant for others in exile to relax with some cold water...It was a hot, sticky afternoon and we were all keen to freshen up before heading to the main venue for registration and initial meetings. No one really needed the extra layers, and yet I felt very much at home just making sure folk were ok. I bagged myself a room upgrade üòÜ. Be kind.

43 people attended the retreat, I have 15 pages of notes. I spoke to all but 4, circling the names of everyone I met and applying an old Housemaster's trick to remember something about them - each one was different and special. We were united in our love for Jesus and our sense of call to serve the Methodist Church. Wow.

People didn't seem nervous but there were some who will have been very - the retreat team's ability to shift from stable, encouraging, affirming, challenging leading of retreat task to supporting some real moments of brokenness was inspirational. It was important that others recognised these moments too, treading gently. Respecting space and reading the room was very important.

I had planned for the drive home (about 5 hours) to be an opportunity to reflect on everything that had gone on. Traffic was light(ish), reflection was hard - there was too much. I had shared how hard I have to work on inner stillness - bombing up the M6 is not conducive to achieving it.

A mile from home I was the car following a head‚Äìon collision. Emergency services arranged, people checked, cars made safe...I then sat with a member from our church for an hour as she was cut free. She and her husband were taken to hospital. All will survive.

The retreat was sandwiched between moments of pastoral care; delivered in the most appropriate and people-focussed way that the situation demanded. It is fast becoming an expressible and lived-by cornerstone of my ministry (a rather bold statement). I am reminded of the time a boy was distraught by being unable to find a matching pair of socks. At that time, in that moment, it is all that mattered. (albeit briefly!).

I was able to be me.

posts.html:
I'm posting this after the last of the Advisory Panel Conversations.

Question: Do you know the best mind-mapping software?

Answer: Are you a 17 year old preparing for his A Levels?

I can always rely on my colleagues to bring me back down to earth. I've been a proponent of mind-mapping in education for many years but...confession time...I've never actually really sat down and produced one. Until now.

The Methodist Church's approach to this panel is genius:

  • It is fair.
  • It is testing.
  • It uses successful strategies common in secular (real world?) interviews to identify the characteristics of the 'interviewee'.
  • In most guidance and documentation the panel is referred to as a 'conversation' (see Page 6: https://media.methodist.org.uk/media/documents/G.1.1_Guide_to_DOV_Part_One.pdf)
  • From the very beginning of DOV1, unprompted, it has been made clear that the questions asked during this conversation are unknown. This was mentioned by my accompanist before and after the retreat, and during the retreat itself.
  • Known factors:
    • Three members + Accompanist
    • 4 Possible Outcomes

There are some immediate challenges that might be obvious but are worth noting.

  • This isn't a job interview
    • There isn't a defined 'job description'...but see below re: recommended note-to-self re: reading.
  • This is another step towards a life changing shift in response to a call from God.
    • So...it's not a job interview.
  • It is a milestone moment.

I have also wrestled with the term advisory.

It is important to remember that the DOV1 Advisory Group are providing considered advice and suggestions but the decision about your next step remains entirely your decision. If you choose to offer as a candidate through DOV2, you will have opportunity through your portfolio and at the DOV2 Connexional Committee to explain your response to their advice.

Honestly, how affirming would it be if three people I've never met before, in the space of an hour, discern that they are as enthusiastic about testing my call formally through the offering phase into DOV2 and beyond?

That bit is obvious. And I'll come back to the 'wrestle-factor'...

So how do I prepare? In a doggedly determined and intense fashion it appears. No way? Yup.

If I was on the panel appeared to be where I started. There are snippets of information about the purpose of the Advisory Panel's conversation:

https://media.methodist.org.uk/media/documents/G.1.1_Guide_to_DOV_Part_One.pdf

They will give you the opportunity to explain your experiences that have led you to this point.
Panels meet all those who are discerning ordained vocation to listen to their call to ordained ministry and discuss this with them.

I cannot stress what a gold mine the Methodist Church website is:

But The Advisory Panel already knows that and they will want to know more about me...not what the website says. However, I would gently suggest that reading G.3, G.4, G.5 and G.6 again is a must:

I remember that the purpose of the accompanist relationship, amongst other beautiful things, is to discuss and complete the elements of D.4. It's been very useful to use the completed version of this as a framework for preparation for the Advisory Panel.

And I realise that I'm jumping around a bit here but prior to each meeting with my accompanist I broke down each section we were going to address of D.4 and applied some pretty extensive research and reading around each of them to understand the expectations and to look at my own practice, position, and status beforehand. It would allow us, together, to identify areas that require more prayer, thought and reflection. To do this I used the 'Guidance for Accompanists' (A.5)'. It's all out there.

Still, I'm not sure this is quite enough preparation. When I look at the guidance for DOV2 it is so extensive. Layout templates, workshops, really specific detail on the expectations of what to produce and how. If this is sounding a little obsessive? I'm ok with that. Just wait.

I started to fire off snippets into my journal as topics cropped up whilst reviewing everything that had happened so far: Call, Methodism, Presbyteral Ministry, Process, Experience, Events, Moments, Social Holiness, The Sacraments, Liturgy, Literature, Prayer life, Devotions, Reading, Bible Passages, Hymns, Me, Current Issues, Future of the Church, Impact on family, DOV1 Retreat reflections...Just one or two word prompters as thoughts came up. It is an hour long conversation.

One sleepless night I went back to the 'Have the Methodist Church really never defined what this Advisory Group / Panel is looking for?'...and tucked away on Page 33 onwards of the 2022 Methodist Council Part 2 Conference Minutes...but specifically 6.2 from Page 39 onwards, (obsessive? I'm still ok with that), a treasure trove of the sorts of things that might form part of the conversation and everything that has taken place up to that point. Nothing read here is a surprise. It is all is in-line with my specific Advisory Panel journal snippets, my fuller journal reflections, my time with my accompanist...and how I'm feeling about all of this.

So back to how did I prepare? Well I took all of this and then went to town using the strategies employed by a 17 year old preparing for his A Levels:

A really important caveat: This probably doesn't make any sense, whatsoever, to anyone...except me. Why? Because it is my mind map. My mind. Nobody else's. It is exposing, raw, and has been so, so helpful.

These were my notes for the Advisory Panel meeting. It has happened.

How did I feel it went? Well. I was able to be me, I was nervous (obviously) but prepared, and as such felt safe in my 'space of readiness'. I don't know if that's a phrase but it might become one. The preparedness gave me a confidence to just be me. A recurring theme. And that brings me back to the wrestle.

Of the 4 outcomes that could feature in the D.5 letter: (Page 6 of G.1.1):

  1. Continue into candidating.
  2. Undertake a shadowing experience or do some other defined form of preparation between June and September and then continue into candidating.
  3. Explore further before returning to candidate (either through attending ‚ÄòExplore‚Äô or through another route).
  4. Explore a different form of vocation

A long, into the night, conversation with Margie after the Advisory Panel followed. Of course we went straight to this point:

It is important to remember that the DOV1 Advisory Group are providing considered advice and suggestions but the decision about your next step remains entirely your decision.

But what if it isn't the first..or second? 'I can't not be me'. Said in the same unquestionable and grammatically challenging manner that I tell myself 'God isn't elsewhere'.

So, this is the wrestle; if these three learned, experienced people do not discern that I am ready to test this call formally, what do I do? I can't ignore it.

What if it is the first? Wow. Reflecting on that in the portfolio and at the DOV2 Connextional Committee will probably be a bit more straight forward.

The experience of the panel itself and meeting the people on it was another 'forever' moment and I continue to be genuinely and deeply humbled by the efforts of all those I have encountered so far as we work together on this Holy Shift.

To end...

Still, I'm not sure this is quite enough preparation. When I look at the guidance for DOV2 it is so extensive. Layout templates, workshops, really specific detail on the expectations of what to produce and how. If this is sounding a little obsessive? I'm ok with that. Just wait.

I started to fire off snippets into my journal as topics cropped up whilst reviewing everything that had happened so far: Call, Methodism, Presbyteral Ministry, Process, Experience, Events, Moments, Social Holiness, The Sacraments, Liturgy, Literature, Prayer life, Devotions, Reading, Bible Passages, Hymns, Me, Current Issues, Future of the Church, Impact on family, DOV1 Retreat reflections...Just one or two word prompters as thoughts came up. It is an hour long conversation.

One sleepless night I went back to the 'Have the Methodist Church really never defined what this Advisory Group / Panel is looking for?'...and tucked away on Page 33 onwards of the 2022 Methodist Council Part 2 Conference Minutes...but specifically 6.2 from Page 39 onwards, (obsessive? I'm still ok with that), a treasure trove of the sorts of things that might form part of the conversation and everything that has taken place up to that point. Nothing read here is a surprise. It is all is in-line with my specific Advisory Panel journal snippets, my fuller journal reflections, my time with my accompanist...and how I'm feeling about all of this.

So back to how did I prepare? Well I took all of this and then went to town using the strategies employed by a 17 year old preparing for his A Levels:

A really important caveat: This probably doesn't make any sense, whatsoever, to anyone...except me. Why? Because it is my mind map. My mind. Nobody else's. It is exposing, raw, and has been so, so helpful.

These were my notes for the Advisory Panel meeting. It has happened.

How did I feel it went? Well. I was able to be me, I was nervous (obviously) but prepared, and as such felt safe in my 'space of readiness'. I don't know if that's a phrase but it might become one. The preparedness gave me a confidence to just be me. A recurring theme. And that brings me back to the wrestle.

Of the 4 outcomes that could feature in the D.5 letter: (Page 6 of G.1.1):

 1. Continue into candidating.
 2. Undertake a shadowing experience or do some other defined form of preparation between June and September and then continue into candidating.
 3. Explore further before returning to candidate (either through attending ‚ÄòExplore‚Äô or through another route).
 4. Explore a different form of vocation

A long, into the night, conversation with Margie after the Advisory Panel followed. Of course we went straight to this point:

It is important to remember that the DOV1 Advisory Group are providing considered advice and suggestions but the decision about your next step remains entirely your decision.

But what if it isn't the first..or second? 'I can't not be me'. Said in the same unquestionable and grammatically challenging manner that I tell myself 'God isn't elsewhere'.

So, this is the wrestle; if these three learned, experienced people do not discern that I am ready to test this call formally, what do I do? I can't ignore it.

What if it is the first? Wow. Reflecting on that in the portfolio and at the DOV2 Connextional Committee will probably be a bit more straight forward.

The experience of the panel itself and meeting the people on it was another 'forever' moment and I continue to be genuinely and deeply humbled by the efforts of all those I have encountered so far as we work together on this Holy Shift.

To end...

posts.html:
I'd slipped away from the desk to catch up with new friends from the KSAT circuit who had just returned from their travels. At 11.19, having justified to ourselves that a second coffee was needed, it landed.

Remember, this could be 4 outcomes:

  1. Continue into candidating.
  2. Undertake a shadowing experience or do some other defined form of preparation between June and September and then continue into candidating.
  3. Explore further before returning to candidate (either through attending ‚ÄòExplore‚Äô or through another route).
  4. Explore a different form of vocation

Result: 1. Continue into candidating.

The letter, written by the panel of the people who met me, was succinct and stated that they had discerned a clear call. Reading it now brings tears to my eyes.

It goes on to state that this is a good time for me to offer as a candidate for ordained ministry and that this is the right path of discernment for me at this time.

The guidance is genuinely offered and comes with strong encouragement.

I am very aware, and have held firmly in my prayers this week, of those who may have received different advice than that they were hoping for. They will be surrounded by the love and support of those closest to them but there will be 'an edge' that they will be dealing with. God is with them.

So, D.5 is now in hand and now some very careful management of communication is needed in the right order. This isn't a 'cold' response, it is a practical, context-based next step and has been planned - the impact on what comes next is 'big stuff'.

Family > Church (a) > Work > Church (b):

Margie was of course quietly thrilled. The 'I told you so' was so gently delivered. She knew of the what-if wrestles, she knows the impact that this has on what our next chapter looks like for all of us. She spoke to her mum, and texted her brothers. I let my parents know.

Church (a), The letter gets sent directly to my Superintendent, District Chair and Minister...All delighted, gently delighted.

The District Chair has sent on to those i/c Ministry & Vocation and the Superintendent, Mission Area Lead and Deputy Chair who will be in post fully from September.

I looped in Janice, Andrew and the KSAT Superintendent with a mix of visits, calls and texts. All delighted, gently delighted.

Margie and I had discussed, and I had a follow-up with Janice, about letting my boss know. C.1 clearly allows for the employer reference only to be taken up after recommendation for training has been made (so towards the end of DOV2). To do this properly, I'm going to need the support of the establishment I've been part of for nearly 20 years and Margie for nearly 30. We have all been together for the majority of our professional lives.

Margie and I both booked in for the following day. We worked on the 'script'; some of this will be a surprise, but not all of it (hopefully), and I wanted to make sure I was presenting the timescales, process and next steps in such a way that our Headmaster was clear of the reasons, what-ifs and the impact but also my commitment to my time at School.

He 100% 'got it'. The conversation was hallmarked by support, encouragement and warmth. He had observed, over the last few years, a 'shift'. He is delighted, gently delighted.

Church (b), happens this Sunday. I'm leaving that messaging to our Minister, Andy.

DOV2 Application C.1, C.3 and a certified copy of my passport has now been sent.

It's time to cross. I am delighted, gently delighted.

posts.html:
There are some key takeaways (for me!) from the portfolio workshop I've just attended put on by the superb folk from The Learning Network.

Oh no...another mind map...

I could feel it brewing as the 2-hour session reached its conclusion. It was helpful to share ideas amongst the group of fellow candidates (all of whom were of course at the DOV1 retreat and it was genuinely lovely to catch up, albeit briefly with some familiar faces.

So, two hours of interactive, fast-paced, section-by-section portfolio discussion and guidance, reflection via breakout rooms and an instant share of some thoughts with Margie to bounce around some ideas so here goes.

I've got my notes; a single page for each of the sections of the portfolio that were discussed. There are some connecting threads and patterns that underpin the thematic, holistic nature of the portfolio. I cannot stress how valuable it has been to discuss...not just read...what the guidance in C.7. is actually saying:

C.7 Portfolio Template & Guidance
C.7_Portfolio_Template_and_Guidance.pdf
283 KB

Bouncing around ideas, hearing how others may present their sections is all really helpful. This isn't a competitive pool of people applying for a job; we're candidates...for ordained ministry. Woah.

I think it's important to layer C.7 with G.6, the Criteria for Candidates for Ordained Ministry in the British Methodist Church, from:

G.6 Critieria for Candidates for Ministry
G.6_Critieria_for_Candidates_for_Ministry.pdf
185 KB

But as it was pointed out by the superb folk leading the workshop, creating our portfolio is not a tick-box exercise. We're not creating this against a mark scheme (as such), instead we are using the portfolio as a mechanism 'present ourselves to the church' and to offer evidence of our capacity, ability and potential.

MindMap...underway.
