posts.html:
Ironically the service theme is patience. I'm waiting...

Everything (non-work) I've turned my hand to over the last 10 days or so has been met with a foggy block. Even this article has been sat in my drafts, unfinished, for 5 days!

Now the pressure is on to be 'creative', all of a sudden every ounce of creativity has vanished. Vanished might be a bit dramatic - it's an odd feeling. To even craft together some ideas is really, really hard work.

Two creative pinch points exist right now (beyond this article)...

  1. My service on 'Patience'.
    1. I led a service at the wonderful Kirkby Stephen chapel, very traditional, accessible, actionable relevant message, good hymns, well received. OK, so that's good. The sermon had matured over the preceding week having started in quite a weak form.
    2. My follow-up service which also follows the same theme is in an entirely different setting. It is 'All Together' and the suggestions have been coming in thick and fast
      1. Be creative; we want something a bit different.
      2. Hands-on and practical.
      3. Collaborative; all the people should be doing something or involved somehow.
      4. There may be children; and they could range from 0-16.
      5. It's assessed.
  2. My DOV 2 Portfolio.

I came away from the workshop feeling inspired and organised:

2 of the 6 sections of the portfolio require submissions to be of a 'creative method' and some suggestions are made in the C.7 Guidance: Mind map, Collage, Art work, Poem, Video of a powerpoint presentation, Dramatic story-telling on video, Diagram, Video of drama or dance, Photo of a 3D sculpture, Song.

And I've got myself in a spin about these two sections:

DOV2 Panel: "So, Matt, tell me about Section E where you have drawn...something...and how this relates to your call to ordained ministry".

Matt: "It doesn't. It's rubbish. I can't paint or draw, I can't settle on a style and it always comes out looking weird. What you're looking at now bears no resemblance to what was in my head. Frankly, I'm embarrassed that I've submitted something that should only feature on the fridge of some proud parents of a three-year-old"

DOV2 Panel: [Pause]

Matt: "But, I do see God in all things".

DOV2 Panel: [Pause]

See! That's how all that could unfold. It won't. But it might.

posts.html:
The brief for the all together worship service as mentioned here:

  1. Be creative; we want something a bit different.
  2. Hands-on and practical.
  3. Collaborative; all the people should be doing something or involved somehow.
  4. There may be children; and they could range from 0-16.
  5. It's assessed.

Oh, and it was only to be 45 minutes.

I went for balance. The majority of the congregation get much from 'steady' well-known hymns, a clear, accessible message and something actionable and tangible for the week ahead. So I needed to weave this in as the dominant trait whilst also introducing things that cover 1-4. This is how it went...

They have done a caf√©-style setup before. So I went for that. Tables, chairs (no coffee until afterwards).

Puzzles and games of patience obtained. Each table had:

  • A Rubik's cube
  • A wire-game
  • A Jenga
  • An envelope that said 'do not open...yet'.

Part 1: Some (too dark) AI generated images of my patience being tested. These needed to be more generic; perhaps more gentle.

The children up front to try the buzzy-wire-game. This felt a bit unneeded - everyone should have given this a go for a few minutes.

Some prayers, a welcome and call to worship, a strong opening hymn (remembering balance).

A whole-congregation attempt at some patience...x 2 of this. This was well recieved.

Part 2:

The core message. Noticing inner-stillness in others, noticing patience as a fruit of the spirit I admire and want more of. Seeing Jesus in others and wanting more of it isn't coveting, it isn't envy or jealousy. It is growth. We grow in Him. We‚Äôre transformed through Him. posts.html:
If you look in Matthew, Mark and Luke, Thomas barely gets a mention, just a name on a list of twelve ordinary people called to do something extraordinary.

It‚Äôs in John‚Äôs Gospel that we really get an idea of who Thomas was. This is breathtaking...

When Jesus heard that his friend Lazarus was dying, he delayed going back to Judea, because it was dangerous. The authorities were already plotting to kill him. The disciples were terrified. And yet Thomas was the one who spoke up and said, ‚ÄúLet us also go, that we may die with him‚Äù?

Not a doubter, more a companion ready to risk everything.

Later, when Jesus tells them he‚Äôs going to prepare a place for them in his Father‚Äôs house, he says: ‚ÄúYou know the way.‚Äù

The others stay silent, nod politely, maybe hoping someone else will ask the awkward question. It‚Äôs Thomas who dares to say, ‚ÄúLord, we don‚Äôt know where you‚Äôre going. How can we know the way?‚Äù

Thomas, again, honest and brave enough to admit he doesn‚Äôt understand.

And who is it that is missing when Jesus first appears to his disciples after his resurrection? Thomas:

It was perfectly understandable that Thomas wanted proof. He was prepared to stand up to the ten apostles who had seen Jesus come back to life and tell them he wanted more than a wishful happy-ever-after fairy-tale. He needed to be convinced.

Who was it who was the first person to recognise that Jesus was not just a prophet, not just a teacher or miracle-worker, no just Messiah, but Emmanuel, God-with-us? 

It was Thomas.

Thomas was the very first to say to Jesus, "My Lord and my God!":

Heavenly Father, Gracious God,

Thank you for Thomas, for his honesty and his courage. Thank you that you meet us in our questions as much as in our certainties.

Help us to bring you our doubts without fear, our longings without shame, and our hopes without pretending.

Grant us faith that grows deeper through reflection, and trust that leads us to say with Thomas, ‚ÄúMy Lord and my God.‚Äù

Amen.

A few weeks ago I had a panel discussion, and one of the members of the panel was the Chairman of The Bible Society. (Stop it!)

Last night I found myself in a somewhat bizarre Zoom moment; on one computer in my study I had the Local Preachers and Worship Leaders (new) Circuit meeting taking place and in parallel, on a laptop out of sight, I had The Church Mission Society's webinar on a report the Bible Society has just published called ‚ÄòThe Quiet Revival‚Äô.

For years we‚Äôve heard the same comments repeated:

‚ÄúChurch is dying.‚Äù ‚ÄúFaith is fading away.‚Äù ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt believe anymore.‚Äù

If someone had said these things to us we‚Äôd have probably nodded along, thinking, well, yes, that‚Äôs just how it is now.

We're wrong...

The Bible Society has now published their research paper called The Quiet Revival. And it‚Äôs showing us that something remarkable is happening. Right now.

  • Since 2018, churchgoing has risen by over 50%. That‚Äôs millions more people gathering, praying, reading the Bible.
  • The biggest growth has come from young adults; 18 to 24-year-olds. In fact, over a fifth of young men in that age group are now regular churchgoers.

It would be easy to think maybe they‚Äôre just coming along for a sense of community and community does matter, especially when so many young people feel lonely or anxious.

But it‚Äôs more than that.

The report shows that these new churchgoers are actively practising faith:

  • Nearly 70% are reading the Bible weekly, not just listening passively.
  • Most are praying regularly.
  • They‚Äôre seeking to follow Jesus, not just sit in a pew.

I love that sample sizes used in this research give a 1% margin of error at a 99% confidence level. The data is reliable.

One of the most encouraging findings is the difference faith is making in people‚Äôs lives: Churchgoers report feeling more hopeful about the future and less likely to feel anxious or depressed. They feel more connected to their local communities.

At a time when so many people are struggling with mental health and isolation, the Church is becoming (again) a place of belonging and purpose. Thank God.

Even people who do not currently go to church are open:

  • More than a third of young adults said they‚Äôd come to a service if a friend invited them.
  • Half said they‚Äôd be glad if someone prayed for them.
  • Many are curious to learn more about the Bible.

We might have assumed no one wants to hear about faith anymore. That's just not the case. People are longing for meaning, for connection, for something solid to stand on.

Of course, there are challenges. Young Christians are passionate, but:

  • Many feel unsure how to read the Bible or talk about it confidently.
  • They‚Äôre sometimes shaken by what the culture says about faith.

If anything this is an invitation to all of us to come alongside, to learn together, to grow in understanding. To be encouragers. To be good listeners. To be willing to share our own stories of faith.

This research shows that God doesn‚Äôt rely on perfect strategies. He works through relationships. Through ordinary people who are willing to say, ‚ÄúCome and see.‚Äù

  • Instead of us feeling anxious about decline, we can be part of something quietly and steadily growing.
  • Instead of assuming no one‚Äôs interested, we can trust that many are more open than we realise.

So we can and should; pray with confidence, share our faith with humility and welcome others with warmth.

This quiet revival isn‚Äôt just a statistic. It‚Äôs a movement of the Spirit. And each of us has a part to play.

I‚Äôve just come back from three days at Cliff College, this came round rather quickly:

The course, Ministry in the Methodist Tradition, was a tapestry of Church history, moments of revival, awkward transitions, messy people, and surprising grace.

Andrew Stobart, the new Principal of the College, led the lectures; 10 sessions almost back to back and a group of 8 of us spent most of the three days on the edge of our seats. The standard of teaching was at a level I'd never experienced. Simply outstanding!

A few observations I‚Äôve brought back with me...

We‚Äôve never stood still, even when it looks like we have. Even when it feels like nothing is happening God‚Äôs people have always been in motion and more often than not, that motion comes through moments we weren‚Äôt quite ready for.

We worry about structure, decline, change, tradition, and sometimes we think, ‚ÄúWell, things aren‚Äôt what they used to be‚Äù. But when you look back, I mean really look back, it‚Äôs never been what it used to be.

Wesley didn‚Äôt plan a denomination, he didn't want to 'create' a church. He didn‚Äôt design a movement from a whiteboard. He responded. He watched. He took risks, and often, he wasn‚Äôt even there when the key bits happened. Oversight was born from his absence. Churches were built when societies outgrew their structures.

And to be honest, some of the most pivotal moments in the Church‚Äôs growth came when Wesley died.

It‚Äôs never really been about the founder, the system or the strategy. It‚Äôs about God at work; quietly, persistently, powerfully and people willing to say yes.

That‚Äôs what the Quiet Revival report last week reminded me of too:

It‚Äôs not about big movements or glossy branding.

It‚Äôs the young adult stepping into a church service they weren‚Äôt invited to, because something pulled them in..and on that note...

Before landing at Cliff, and by way of extreme contrasts, I had attended the Henley Festival. It was superb.

In conversation with people in their early twenties, it quickly became apparent that they had an interest, a real, tangible interest in exploring their faith, but hadn‚Äôt found the push to step into a church on a Sunday morning and experience that community and fellowship gifted by our time of worship.  They‚Äôve now been encouraged to do so and I can't wait to hear how they got on. Sometimes, challenging apathy and giving confidence that 'all will be well', is enough.

Straight after Henley, en-route to Cliff College, I stopped off at Chesterfield's Church of St Mary and All Saints, (Crooked Spire) Church. I arrived in time to join Morning Worship, I was the only one, and the presider didn't notice me so carried on without me, in the Lady Chapel. I thanked him afterwards, he replied "you're welcome". Love that.

What's my takeaway from the week?

It‚Äôs the prayer said quietly over someone who isn‚Äôt sure if they believe, but feels something stir. It‚Äôs the invitation that was half-awkwardly given, but entirely Spirit-led.

We sometimes ask, ‚ÄúWhere is God in all this?‚Äù

The answer is: probably somewhere we‚Äôre not looking.

  • We think revival is loud. But often, it‚Äôs patient.
  • We think church history is neat. But it‚Äôs rarely tidy.
  • We think faith is about certainty. But often, it‚Äôs about stepping out not knowing what comes next.

Cliff reminded me that we are part of a bigger, wilder story than we let ourselves believe. That our denominations, whether Methodist, Anglican, Catholic, URC, Baptist or something else, were all born of surprise.

None of it was meant to happen the way it did. But it did. And here we are. And here we stay, for a moment, but not still.

If there‚Äôs one thread that runs through every revival, every reformation, every gathering of awkward saints and stumbling disciples, it‚Äôs this: God keeps moving.

And if we‚Äôre paying attention, we can move with Him.

The encouragement is simple:

  • Look again at our church. Look again at our own and our church stories, notice the chaos. We mustn‚Äôt assume the good stuff is over. Because it isn‚Äôt.
  • The Church has always been changing. And in every generation, it‚Äôs the people who notice the movement, who catch the wind of the Spirit, that get to be part of what comes next.
  • We don‚Äôt need to lead a revival. We just need to be ready to respond. Faithfully, presently and willing to move when God says ‚ÄúNow.‚Äù 

God of the pilgrim Church,
Thank You for the surprising ways You move.
Through history, through absence, through Your people,
You‚Äôve never stopped calling us forward.

Help us not to be fearful of change,
But to trust that You are in it.
May we walk with courage,
Speak with grace,
And be willing to say yes to what You are already doing.

 In Jesus‚Äô name, Amen.

I have recently become very aware that my daily devotions fail to follow a regular pattern, the cadence isn't established. I keep saying I‚Äôll get into a rhythm, but I end up playing random notes at different times of the day.

On Sunday, I had one of those brilliant, unplanned, fellowship conversations after a service I led at a small chapel in Dufton. Timed perfectly, someone shared with me, unprompted, a similar tussle; he can find accessing God through formalised prayer time uncomfortable and sometimes a little fake.

We reflected on my favourite phrase, 'God isn't elsewhere', and that our constant dialogues with God, that companionship we find during our conversations with God can be just as accessible, if not more so. They can allow for a richness of dialogue and an opportunity to listen.

We both agreed: those conversational prayers throughout the day, the ones in the car, walking to work (or on his tractor), in the middle of the day, in-between meetings, they can be just as holy as the ones in a pew with a prayer book.

Then came Tuesday night. Or should I say Wednesday morning, 2am to 3am. Sleepless, wide awake, heart racing. Too much on my mind. So what did I do?

I prayed my socks off. I prayed for everything: My family. My work. My Church. My calling. For people I‚Äôd only met once, for people I‚Äôve known forever. For communities broken, and roofs broken.

It was like a prayer floodgate had opened. And then I spent most of yesterday feeling guilty.

Because I thought, wasn‚Äôt I the one saying God doesn‚Äôt need formal prayer slots? Wasn‚Äôt I the one who said the conversational stuff was enough?

And now here I was, doing a 2am mini-retreat.

To cement this conflict, to deepen the contrast, I ended up at a BCP Holy Communion service this morning. You couldn‚Äôt get more formal. More structured. More crafted in its language and it was beautiful.

God was making a point.

What became clear is that there is room for both.

There is room for the spontaneous sigh towards heaven and the carefully worded Collect. Room for the sleepy 2am outpouring and the service book handed down through generations.

He is in the casual ‚ÄúHelp me, Lord‚Äù and the reverent ‚ÄúWe do not presume to come‚Ä¶‚Äù

He is in the rhythm, and in the rupture of that rhythm.

Lord of rhythm and stillness,
Teach us to trust the conversation we‚Äôre already having with You.
Let us not measure our prayer life by its neatness or noise
but by the nearness of You in it all.

May we find You in the silence and the sleeplessness,
in the Sunday service, the school run, and the rat race.
in whispered fears and joyful thanks.
Amen.

posts.html:
A few weeks ago I wrote about The church never standing still, and how God's people have always been in motion, I‚Äôve reflected upon this and there is a gentle challenge, a holy balance, to all of this.

If we look to disrupt church or change too much of what makes us church we may risk not being in synergy with God.

Methodism has its Way of Life, a simple but powerful framework: prayer, worship, notice, care, learn, open, share, live, tell, challenge, flourish,serve. Other traditions have their own guides: The Church of England speak of the Rule of Life, Catholics of the Catechism, the Reformed tradition of the Confessions of Faith. Different shapes, different words, but all of them saying the same thing:

Don‚Äôt get lost. Keep coming back to God.

Why? Because if we forget to return, if we forget to be obedient to God‚Äôs word, we risk becoming 'shoppers of faith.': Picking and choosing the bits we like, leaving the rest on the shelf and in that subtle temptation, we begin, without even noticing, to make God in our image, instead of letting Him make us in His.

Now, obedience is not a fashionable word. It sounds heavy. It sounds like rules and control but John Wesley had a way of turning words like that upside down. Just as he said repentance is the doorway to freedom, Christian joy is joy in obedience.

Obedience, in the biblical sense, is not about coercion. It is about listening, really listening, to the word of God. Hearing it. Responding to it. Trusting that the One who calls us back does so in love.

This is where my dog, Riley comes in...

When we take her out for a walk, she‚Äôs perfect, until she isn‚Äôt...

...A rabbit bolts, another dog appears, or something unmentionable smells irresistible. Suddenly, we don‚Äôt exist. No matter how much we call, she ignores us. But what she doesn‚Äôt know is this: We‚Äôre not calling her back to ruin her fun. We‚Äôre calling her back because we love her and because we don‚Äôt want her to eat something that will make her ill or run into the road and get hurt.

Obedience is like that. God calls us back not to limit us but to free us. Not to deny us joy but to protect us and lead us into something far better.

So yes, we should welcome talk of revival and the excitement of what new things God is doing in His Church.

But we must also remember: revival begins not with us changing God, but with God changing us.

And that happens when we listen. When we return. When we trust that God‚Äôs voice, even when it feels countercultural, even when it cuts against our instincts, God's is the only voice that can lead us into life.

Sometimes, the most radical thing the Church can do is not run ahead but kneel.

And when we do, we will discover that in obedience, chosen freely, joyfully, we are not restricted, but released.

posts.html:
Yesterday was the one day of the year when we left-handers are celebrated for surviving in a world designed by right-handers. A world where scissors and computer mice seem deliberately awkward, and spiral-bound notebooks are nearly useless.

They say we left-handers are in touch with the right hemisphere of our brains, the one often linked with creativity. It‚Äôs a proud heritage: Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Beethoven, Jimi Hendrix, Bill Gates, Barack Obama, and a surprisingly large number of US presidents and British monarchs, all lefties.

We‚Äôre in a bit of a club, us lefties.

And as I read about this last night having totally failed to mark my left-handedness I thought...

...As Christians, we‚Äôre in a ‚Äúclub‚Äù too.

United by something deeper than handedness. We are part of one body, one family, one worldwide fellowship of faith. We don‚Äôt get VIP badges, silver or gold membership tiers. No one earns "Platinum Christian‚Äù status in this club. We all hold the same lifetime membership, freely given by grace, sealed in baptism, renewed each time we gather in the name of Jesus and share bread and wine together.

And with that free membership come the perks. The presence of the Holy Spirit, the assurance of God‚Äôs love, the joy of fellowship, the hope of resurrection. 

And, just as Methodists still have the tradition of the annual membership ticket, not because we‚Äôre ‚Äúchecking up‚Äù but because it‚Äôs a joyful reminder that we belong, so our faith reminds us every day: we are part of this, and we are never alone.

Which brings us to today, A Level results day.  For years and years I‚Äôve spoken to teenagers as they get their results, for many it‚Äôs a day full of nerves, celebrations, tears, and sometimes shock. That moment of opening the envelope, or clicking the results online, or getting the phone call can feel like the world narrowing to a single instant.

For some, it‚Äôs joy and relief. For others, disappointment. For some, it‚Äôs bewilderment, ‚ÄúWhat now?‚Äù, and in all of it, there‚Äôs that strange realisation that you are not entirely in control.

Our worth is not determined by a grade on a piece of paper. God‚Äôs plans are not thwarted by a B instead of an A. In fact, Scripture is full of people whose ‚Äúresults‚Äù were not what they expected; Moses was rejected before becoming a leader, Peter failed spectacularly before becoming the rock on which the church was built, Paul went from persecutor to preacher.

When we place our future in God‚Äôs hands, the next step, whether it‚Äôs the one we planned or an entirely different road, becomes part of a bigger story. A left turn, if you like, can still lead to the right destination.

Lord,

Thank you that we are all part of your family; different, gifted in our own ways, yet united in Christ.

Bless those who celebrate today, and comfort those who are disappointed.

Guide all who are facing decisions and next steps, that they may know your presence in the uncertainty and your joy in the successes.

And remind us all that your membership is for life, and for eternity, freely given to all who will receive it. Amen.

L&M both have friends staying over and this morning, over breakfast, coffee and conversation as the teenagers slept, we hit on that question every parent dreads on a rainy day: ‚ÄúWhat can we do to keep two teenagers entertained?‚Äô

I rather unhelpfully suggested after going into the L's room yesterday that you could ‚ÄúGive her a bin bag and get her to tidy her room.‚Äù ‚ÄúHonestly, 90% of it could go straight in the bag, it‚Äôs all tat!‚Äù

I confessed, in what was fast becoming a lofty monologue, that in an ideal world, I‚Äôd settle for just three things:

  1. A comfortable chair,
  2. A good light,
  3. My laptop.

That‚Äôs me content. Minimal.  I was ‚Äòsent‚Äô to work, because frankly, it was all nonsense...

I‚Äôve inherited my Granny‚Äôs tastes which were always expensive and includes furniture that‚Äôs so heavy and massive it feels like it was designed to outlast empires.

And so, like many of us, I live in the tension between simplicity and sentimentality. Between needs and desires or wants.  We will all have possessions that have value because of where they‚Äôve come from. Some of my possessions are nothing but extravagance.

It reminded me of the genius of Desert Island Discs; that deceptively simple question: What would you take with you?

Strip away everything else, what remains essential? What reveals what we treasure most? And that‚Äôs the heart of the lectionary reading:

Luke 12:32‚Äì40 (NIV): 32 ‚ÄúDo not be afraid, little flock, for your Father has been pleased to give you the kingdom. 33 Sell your possessions and give to the poor. Provide purses for yourselves that will not wear out, a treasure in heaven that will never fail, where no thief comes near and no moth destroys. 34 For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
35 ‚ÄúBe dressed ready for service and keep your lamps burning, 36 like servants waiting for their master to return from a wedding banquet, so that when he comes and knocks they can immediately open the door for him. 37 It will be good for those servants whose master finds them watching when he comes. Truly I tell you, he will dress himself to serve, will have them recline at the table and will come and wait on them. 38 It will be good for those servants whose master finds them ready, even if he comes in the middle of the night or toward daybreak. 39 But understand this: If the owner of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would not have let his house be broken into. 40 You also must be ready, because the Son of Man will come at an hour when you do not expect him.‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt about going without for the sake of it. It‚Äôs not anti-stuff. But it is about checking what we really value. Jesus is drawing a direct connection between what we treasure and who we are. Our heart follows our investments.

And then there‚Äôs the church itself. I walk past two on the way to work. Stunning spaces have been built, all intended to honour God, and they do, and rightly so. I love them. The stained glass, the heavy wood, the sense of grandeur and reverence, the history and memories. But even in worship, we can drift from glorifying God to preserving our own traditions. 

I think we honour God best when we remember He‚Äôs not looking for polish, He‚Äôs looking for presence.

Are we living lightly enough to receive what God is already offering? Or are we so full of our own collections, our to-do lists, our ambitions, our clutter, our worries and fears, our hopes and dreams, that we haven‚Äôt left room for The Kingdom?

So I suppose the question may be: what would we take to our desert island of faith? What can we genuinely not do without? And what might be time to let go?

The very first line of the reading, reads like a headline.

Do not be afraid, little flock, for your Father has been pleased to give you the kingdom.

What a line! Tenderness, intimacy, and assurance. We are not urged to generosity from a place of guilt, but from a place of grace. God‚Äôs 'has been pleased'; this isn‚Äôt reluctant charity from above, but joyful giving from the heart of the Father.

...to give you the kingdom.

Not trade it. Not sell it. Not loan it. Give it.

And so, if we begin with what we‚Äôve got maybe we should let it also guide us to what God wants for us.

35 ‚ÄúBe dressed ready for service and keep your lamps burning, 36 like servants waiting for their master to return from a wedding banquet, so that when he comes and knocks they can immediately open the door for him.

The posture of readiness. A servant on the lookout. The lamp still burning. The coat already on.

Jesus isn‚Äôt talking about fear. He‚Äôs talking about attentiveness. A kind of spiritual agility. Living not weighed down by treasures and stuff, but alive to God‚Äôs movement, alert to where He might appear.

And there‚Äôs an incredible twist in the middle of the passage:

he will dress himself to serve, will have them recline at the table and will come and wait on them

The master becomes the servant. It‚Äôs a foreshadowing of the Last Supper. Of Christ kneeling to wash feet. Of Calvary. And of the great banquet to come.

God doesn‚Äôt want empty gestures. He doesn‚Äôt demand our readiness as a test. He delights in meeting us where we are, but calls us to be awake to His coming. Are we awake? Are we really watching for God in our lives? Or are we nodding off, dulled by routine, spiritual apathy, or too much clutter?

The closing image in is slightly ominous:

If the owner of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would not have let his house be broken into.

That‚Äôs not a threat. It‚Äôs a wake-up call. The Kingdom is coming, whether we‚Äôre ready or not. So we need to be ready. Not in fear, but in faith. Not anxiously, but expectantly.

We need to be thankful, generous and awake. Because God‚Äôs already moving, already giving and already preparing a place for us. We don‚Äôt have to strive. We don‚Äôt have to store up. Calvary is enough.

So, last night in our house there was one of those ‚Äòmoments‚Äô‚Ä¶LRGM, who‚Äôs just starting Year 9, suddenly announced, ‚ÄúI hate school. I don‚Äôt want to go.‚Äù

Now, she didn‚Äôt really mean it, not deep down. It was nerves, a bit of apprehension about what was coming and this morning a completely different story. She was excited, looking forward to her friends, and ready to go.  For some reason she took the car keys‚Ä¶

That swing between dread and delight is something we all know when we face a new beginning. The first day at a new job, moving house, even turning up to a group or a church for the first time; there‚Äôs that little voice that says, ‚ÄúWhat if I don‚Äôt fit? What if I can‚Äôt do this?‚Äù And then, often enough, it turns out to be fine. Sometimes more than fine, good.

The Bible shows us the same human wobble. Peter, bold as brass, steps out of the boat to walk on water then the very next moment he‚Äôs sinking because fear got the better of him.  Or the disciples on Easter morning, weighed down with grief, looking back at the cross, until suddenly they‚Äôre running to the tomb and hope bursts into life.

Paul captures this beautifully when he says:

Philippians 3:13‚Äì14 (NIV): 13 Brothers and sisters, I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But one thing I do: Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, 14 I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.

Not because the past doesn‚Äôt matter, but because God calls us to keep moving forward and it‚Äôs not just what‚Äôs behind us, Jesus, in the Sermon on the Mount, reminds us not to get lost in tomorrow either:

Matthew 6:34 (NIV): 34 Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own.

And of course, the ultimate new beginning in Scripture is right there in John 1:

John 1:1 (NIV): 1 In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

The whole story of Jesus, God, stepping into the world, is the greatest new beginning of them all. It reminds us that God has always been there: in the past, right here in the present, and waiting in the future.

So maybe that‚Äôs the encouragement for us at the start of a new school year, a new job, a new season. We don‚Äôt need to erase yesterday. We don‚Äôt need to have tomorrow all figured out. We just need to remember that God holds every moment.

Whether we‚Äôre saying, ‚ÄúI hate this,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait,‚Äù the truth is the same. God is already there. And that makes new beginnings not just something to survive, but something to step into with hope.

At a service on Sunday, I prayed this during intercessions:

‚ÄúGod of all peoples and nations, we thank You for the good gift of belonging, of culture, of heritage, and of community. But Lord, we confess that what begins as love for one‚Äôs country can too easily harden into superiority, prejudice, and even hatred. When national pride tips into nationalism, it blinds us to the humanity of others. It fuels bigotry and racism, and it builds walls where You call us to build bridges.
We pray for those who arrive among us with nothing but hope, those who leave behind homes, histories, and loved ones in search of safety. Too often they are met with suspicion or rejection, when what they long for is shelter and welcome. 
Lord, forgive us when fear shapes our response instead of love. Break down the barriers of suspicion and hostility. Teach us to see every stranger as a neighbour, every neighbour as a brother or sister, and every brother and sister as a bearer of Your image. May Your Church lead the way in showing radical hospitality, generous compassion, and courageous love.‚Äù

I wondered afterwards whether they were a bit close to the wire; whether they came across as more of a sermon than intercession. And maybe they did. But that‚Äôs because these really are concerns that sit heavily on my heart....

Prayers aren‚Äôt always the right place to work these things through. And though I‚Äôve been praying my socks off for a sense of calm surrounding this topic, I‚Äôve turned to the gospel, and I‚Äôve reflected.

In Luke‚Äôs Gospel, the Pharisees and scribes criticise Jesus:

Luke 15:2 (NIV): 2 But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law muttered, ‚ÄúThis man welcomes sinners and eats with them.‚Äù

This was a damning accusation. To eat with someone in that culture was to show acceptance, to join in fellowship, to share your table.

Jesus should, by their standards, have kept himself apart, guarded his reputation, and maintained the purity codes of his community. Instead, he deliberately crossed those boundaries.

Luke goes on to describe how Jesus tells parables about the lost sheep and the lost coin. Both stories are outrageous in their own way; the shepherd leaving ninety-nine sheep unprotected for the sake of one, the woman turning her whole house upside down for a single coin. But that‚Äôs the point: the love of God is extravagant, excessive, reckless by the world‚Äôs standards.

And that‚Äôs what radical hospitality looks like. It is not sensible. It is not cautious. It is not concerned with reputation. It risks the raised eyebrow, the criticism, the whisper of disapproval. Jesus made religious leaders deeply uncomfortable because he didn‚Äôt just preach about God‚Äôs mercy, he embodied it at the table; in real life, with real people.

Now, if prayers on Sunday made those hearing them feel even a little uncomfortable, and I felt uncomfortable writing them because it made me reflect upon my own prejudices, then maybe that‚Äôs not such a bad thing. Discipleship is not about staying comfortable. It‚Äôs about being stretched into the likeness of Christ. And Christ calls us, no tells us, not to draw the circle tighter but to throw the doors wider.

The call of Jesus is as urgent as ever: welcome the stranger, stand with the vulnerable, rejoice over the lost being found. Not because it‚Äôs popular or easy, but because that‚Äôs exactly what God has done for us in Christ.

Radical is the very shape of the Gospel, it‚Äôs not optional. It‚Äôs the Shepherd searching, the woman sweeping, the Father running to embrace the prodigal. It‚Äôs the Son of God sitting at the table with tax collectors and sinners, and with us.

We might ask ourselves who are the people that we find hardest to welcome, I watch the news in despair at the conflict in our streets and around our world. We clash with people we work with, socialise with, live with, pray with...and what might it look like if we opened the door anyway? At a service on Sunday, I prayed this during intercessions:

‚ÄúGod of all peoples and nations, we thank You for the good gift of belonging, of culture, of heritage, and of community. But Lord, we confess that what begins as love for one‚Äôs country can too easily harden into superiority, prejudice, and even hatred. When national pride tips into nationalism, it blinds us to the humanity of others. It fuels bigotry and racism, and it builds walls where You call us to build bridges.

We pray for those who arrive among us with nothing but hope, those who leave behind homes, histories, and loved ones in search of safety. Too often they are met with suspicion or rejection, when what they long for is shelter and welcome.¬†

Lord, forgive us when fear shapes our response instead of love. Break down the barriers of suspicion and hostility. Teach us to see every stranger as a neighbour, every neighbour as a brother or sister, and every brother and sister as a bearer of Your image. May Your Church lead the way in showing radical hospitality, generous compassion, and courageous love.‚Äù

I wondered afterwards whether they were a bit close to the wire; whether they came across as more of a sermon than intercession. And maybe they did. But that‚Äôs because these really are concerns that sit heavily on my heart....

Prayers aren‚Äôt always the right place to work these things through. And though I‚Äôve been praying my socks off for a sense of calm surrounding this topic, I‚Äôve turned to the gospel, and I‚Äôve reflected.

In Luke‚Äôs Gospel, the Pharisees and scribes criticise Jesus:

Luke 15:2 (NIV): 2¬†But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law muttered, ‚ÄúThis man welcomes sinners and eats with them.‚Äù

Luke goes on to describe how Jesus tells parables about the lost sheep and the lost coin. Both stories are outrageous in their own way; the shepherd leaving ninety-nine sheep unprotected for the sake of one, the woman turning her whole house upside down for a single coin. But that‚Äôs the point: the love of God is extravagant, excessive, reckless by the world‚Äôs standards.

And that‚Äôs what radical hospitality looks like. It is not sensible. It is not cautious. It is not concerned with reputation. It risks the raised eyebrow, the criticism, the whisper of disapproval. Jesus made religious leaders deeply uncomfortable because he didn‚Äôt just preach about God‚Äôs mercy, he embodied it at the table; in real life, with real people.

Now, if prayers on Sunday made those hearing them feel even a little uncomfortable, and I felt uncomfortable writing them because it made me reflect upon my own prejudices, then maybe that‚Äôs not such a bad thing. Discipleship is not about staying comfortable. It‚Äôs about being stretched into the likeness of Christ. And Christ calls us, no tells us, not to draw the circle tighter but to throw the doors wider.

The call of Jesus is as urgent as ever: welcome the stranger, stand with the vulnerable, rejoice over the lost being found. Not because it‚Äôs popular or easy, but because that‚Äôs exactly what God has done for us in Christ.

Radical is the very shape of the Gospel, it‚Äôs not optional. It‚Äôs the Shepherd searching, the woman sweeping, the Father running to embrace the prodigal. It‚Äôs the Son of God sitting at the table with tax collectors and sinners, and with us.

posts.html:
This morning I was asked to present to colleagues about the changing digital landscape. We reflected on how quickly things move; new platforms, new behaviours, new technologies; and how overwhelming that can feel. It isn‚Äôt just AI. It‚Äôs the whole online world, reshaping the way children grow up, the way adults teach, the way we all live.

I pulled together a slide that outlined three, general approaches colleagues may wish to adopt, and I had one of those moments, during the presentation at 10am this morning where all of this seemed to connect.  Whether this is change in the digital world or change in the ‚Äòreal world‚Äô:

First: Can‚Äôt ignore it. Must not instil fear.

The digital world is real. It‚Äôs shaping us. To pretend otherwise would be na√Øve. So it is happening or ‚Äòit‚Äô has already happened. But the answer isn‚Äôt to spread fear. Though I did include some challenging statistics:

So, fear is not the answer. Jesus never calls us into fear. Instead, he says:

John 14:27 (NIV): 27 Peace I leave with you; my peace I give you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid.

Second: Develop agility; everyone.

In a fast-moving world, we all need agility; the agility to adapt, to reflect, to change course when necessary. For children, this can feel like constant pressure to keep up. For adults, it can feel like we‚Äôre always running to catch up. But when we are rooted in Christ, we have the stability that allows us to be agile. Because our foundation is sure, we can take risks, we can step out, we can adjust. Hebrews reminds us:

Hebrews 13:8 (NIV): 8 Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever.

That certainty frees us to be flexible in all the other areas of life.

Third: Do not assume. Think different.

Ignore the grammar‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs easy to assume the online world is always harmful, or that children can‚Äôt cope, or that adults can‚Äôt adapt. But we need to think differently. For some, technology is a gift, a creative outlet, even a place of connection. For others, it is exhausting and dangerous. Balance is key. And the same applies to our walk with Christ. We can‚Äôt assume faith is always comfortable. Jesus challenges us as much as he comforts us. He asks us to see the world differently, to value differently, to live differently.

So there is a paradox; the digital landscape feels uncertain, overwhelming, and constantly shifting. But our faith is both the opposite and the same. It is anchored, unchanging, steady in Christ. And yet, in holding on to that certainty, we are set free to live lives that are agile, adaptable, and open to transformation.
